para.paratext: Georgia has largely adopted the language of Fed. R. Evid. 801(d)(2)(E).

Admissions shall not be excluded by the hearsay rule. An admission is a statement offered against a party which is: … A statement by a coconspirator of a party during the course and in furtherance of the conspiracy, including a statement made during the concealment phase of a conspiracy.
A conspiracy need not be charged in order to make a statement admissible under this subparagraph.

The italicized language was added to the federal rule, which requires proof of the existence of a conspiracy prior to the admission of the statement and that “[t]he contents of the statement shall be considered but are not alone sufficient to establish … the existence of the conspiracy and the participation therein of the declarant and the party against whom the statement is offered.”
Georgia case law has been ambiguous about the “in furtherance” requirement with some cases requiring it[1] and others not.

A previous distinction between the state and federal practice was that Georgia courts left the final determination as to whether a conspiracy actually existed to the jury,[2] but, in federal court, the issues of the existence of a conspiracy, its pendency, whether the party against whom it was offered was a member, and whether the statement was made in furtherance of the conspiracy were decided by the court under Fed. R. Evid. 104(a).[
3]

Moreover, in Georgia, statements made during the concealment part of the conspiracy are still included as part of co-conspirator exception of O.C.G.A. § 24-8-801(d)(2)(E).[
4] Such statements are often considered analogous to statements by a party's agent or representative and are essentially admitted as an admission by the defendant. In Jones v. State, [5] testimony of an acquaintance of a co-conspirator that the co-conspirator had threatened him several months after the murder was admissible because it was made in furtherance of the conspiracy; the threat was designed to keep law enforcement from discovering the conspiracy. Under O.C.G.A. § 24-8-801(d)(2)(E), once the existence of a conspiracy is proved, “the declarations by any one of the conspirators during the pendency of the criminal project shall be admissible against all.”
This rule applies in both civil and criminal cases.[
6 ] However, while the federal courts require that a conspiracy be proved before the admission of the co-conspirator statements, Georgia courts apply a more lenient standard, requiring that a conspiracy be proved at trial, not necessarily prior to the admission of the statement.[
7] Thus, so long as the evidence of a conspiracy is presented, independent of the co-conspirator's statement, before the close of the evidence, then admission of co-conspirators' statements is allowed.[
8] In Chavers v. State ,[9] the defendant argued that at the time the hearsay testimony was admitted, a conspiracy had not been proved by the state; however, “[w]e do not require that the conspiracy be proven prior to the admission of the evidence in question, but only that a conspiracy was proven at trial.”
[10]

In order to properly admit an admission of a coconspirator under the rule, the proponent of the statement must make a prima facie showing to prove the existence of the conspiracy beyond a reasonable doubt.[
11] Evidence of the conspiracy must be established independent of the coconspirator statements offered.[
12] The prima facie case may be shown on the evidence as a whole,[13] and it does not have to be made prior to the admission of the statement itself. The trial court has broad discretion in the order of proof and may conditionally admit an admission of a coconspirator.[
14]

Evidence of the defendant's and declarant's concerted actions during the time of the alleged offense will establish the conspiracy. For example, in Jones v. State ,[15 ] evidence that the defendant and declarant were together on the night of murder, participated in the murder together, and immediately fled together was sufficient to establish a prima facie case of conspiracy.

The existence of familial relationships between the declarant and defendant, combined with other slight incriminating evidence may establish the conspiracy.[
16]

It is not necessary to show an explicit agreement between the parties.[
17] The essence of conspiracy is a common design, and conduct which discloses a common design may give rise to an inference of conspiracy.

Exculpatory statements by a coconspirator are not admissible as O.C.G.A. § 24-8-801 only contemplates admission of statements “against” the accused.[
18] Additionally, a coconspirator's confession to police in which other alleged conspirators are identified and their participation is described was not made “during the pendency of the criminal project,” and therefore was not admissible.[
19] However, out-of-court statements by a co-conspirator implicating a defendant in a crime are admissible and not in violation of the Confrontation Clause even if the co-conspirator does not testify, provided that the statements are not testimonial, i.e., not intended to establish evidence in a future prosecution, but rather made during and in furtherance of the conspiracy or concealment of it.[
20 ] An incriminating statement was not admissible when a coconspirator's made a statement to the sheriff's investigator which incriminated the accused and terminated the conspiracy.[
21]

Statements made during the “concealment” phase of a crime are admissible.[
22]
Livingston v. State, 268 Ga. 205, 210, 486 S.E.2d 845 (1997).
See also Bourjaily v. U.S., 483 U.S. 171, 183, 107 S. Ct. 2775, 97 L. Ed. 2d 144, 22 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 1105 (1987).
See Mangum v. State, 274 Ga. 573, 555 S.E.2d 451(2001); Castillo v. State, 281 Ga. 579, 642 S.E.2d 8 (2007).
State v. Wilkins, 302 Ga. 156, 805 S.E.2d 868 (2017).
Dublin v. State, 302 Ga. 60, 805 S.E.2d 27 (2017).
Chavers v. State, 304 Ga. 887, 823 S.E.2d 283 (2019).
Smith v. State, 253 Ga. App. 131, 558 S.E.2d 455 (2001).

Codefendant's inculpatory statements made in a conversation occurring the day after the crimes was admissible under hearsay exception for statements of coconspirators where the state presented ample evidence that the defendant and codefendants planned to commit a robbery and further agreed to conceal their role in the crime.
Thorpe v. State, 285 Ga. 604, 678 S.E.2d 913 (2009).

Statements of co-indictee about robbing a store with the defendant were not admissible under the coconspirator exception to the hearsay rule because, apart from the testimony of the witness who relayed the statements, the state offered no other evidence of a conspiracy between the defendant and the co-indictee.
Fisher v. State, 295 Ga. App. 501, 672 S.E.2d 476 (2009).
See Castell v. State, 250 Ga. 776, 301 S.E.2d 234 (1983).
Blalock v. State, 250 Ga. 441, 298 S.E.2d 477 (1983).
See also Bruce v. State, 263 Ga. 273, 430 S.E.2d 745 (1993); Smith v. State, 253 Ga. App. 131, 558 S.E.2d 455 (2001).

Robinson v. State, 175 Ga. App. 769, 772, 334 S.E.2d 358 (1985) (uncle-nephew relationship; “where transactions involving relatives are under review slight circumstances are often sufficient to induce a belief that there was collusion between the parties”). See also, e.g., Smith v. State, 253 Ga. App. 131, 558 S.E.2d 455 (2001) (holding that the inference the defendant took the cocaine to conceal it plus his uncle-nephew relationship with the cocaine supplier combines to establish a prima facie case that the defendant was a willing participant in the conspiracy).
Belmar v. State, 252 Ga. App. 264, 555 S.E.2d 902 (2001).
See O.C.G.A. § 24-8-801(d)(2); Wilson v. State, 271 Ga. 811, 525 S.E.2d 339 (1999) (overruled on other grounds by, O'Kelley v. State, 284 Ga. 758, 670 S.E.2d 388 (2008)).
See also Dennis v. State, 303 Ga. App. 457, 693 S.E.2d 825 (2010).
Livingston v. State, 268 Ga. 205, 210, 486 S.E.2d 845 (1997) (decided under former O.C.G.A. § 24-3-5).

Video recorded statement of coconspirator's interview with sheriff's office investigator did not come within coconspirator exception to rule against hearsay where recorded statements were not made during pendency of criminal project but in response to investigator's questions several days after crimes occurred.
Rayshad v. State, 295 Ga. App. 29, 670 S.E.2d 849 (2008).

But see Allen v. State, 288 Ga. 263, 266–67, 702 S.E.2d 869 (2010), holding coconspirator's statements were made during the pendency of the conspiracy because he had made no confession to police identifying the other conspirators so as to end the conspiracy (citing Arevalo v. State, 275 Ga. 392, 567 S.E.2d 303 (2002) (so long as the conspiracy to conceal the identity of the perpetrators of the offense continues, the parties to such conspiracy are to be considered so much a unit that the declarations of either are admissible against the other)).
Sharber v. State, 268 Ga. App. 365, 601 S.E.2d 732 (2004) (quoting Meadows v. State, 264 Ga. App. 160, 166, 590 S.E.2d 173 (2003)).

See also O'Neill v. State, 285 Ga. 125, 674 S.E.2d 302 (2009) (holding that conspirator's post-arrest statement to police incriminating a coconspirator terminated the conspiracy, rendering the statement admissible only against the declarant); Verdree v. State, 299 Ga. App. 673, 683 S.E.2d 632 (2009) (same).

Knight v. State, 239 Ga. 594, 238 S.E.2d 390 (1977); Duffy v. State, 262 Ga. 249, 250, 416 S.E.2d 734 (1992); Jones v. State, 265 Ga. 84, 453 S.E.2d 716 (1995); Williamson v. State, 285 Ga. App. 779, 648 S.E.2d 118 (2007).
See also Stinski v. State, 286 Ga. 839, 691 S.E.2d 854 (2010).
